text: - Welcome, everybody.
My name is Frank Schwarzenau.

I'm joined here by Brint
O'Hearn from Slalom.

And I'm excited to talk to you
today about Cloud Operations,

about what you guys see
for the next years coming,

and anything that you want to
share with a larger audience.

- Awesome.
- So,
I'm in a partner organization,
I run the Cloud Operations Competency.
And, yeah, over to you.
- Yeah, I'm Brint O'Hearn.

For those that aren't
familiar with Slalom,
we've been a partner with AWS
since basically the beginning of AWS.
So I lead one of our practice teams.

If you're not familiar, we
have about 45 markets globally,
and we've been just announced
as Global Services Partner of the Year.
So, really excited about that,
and thanks, Frank, for having me.

- Yeah, so Slalom is a huge
name in my world, for sure,
in the partner world.

And you've won a lot of
awards very recently.

But for anybody that is
not familiar with Slalom,

could you just maybe
give a couple of details

on how big, what markets,
like, where you operate?
That would be awesome.
- Sure, sure. We're in 45 markets.
We're in eight countries.
We've got about 12,000 consultants,

and we're a business and
technology consulting firm.

So we focus on, like, an
outcome of the customer,
what they wanna do,

and how we can bring in
AWS services and solutions
as a part of a larger outcome.
So that's really what Slalom's known for,
and that's kind of our bread and butter.
Business and technology consulting.
- Awesome.

And I know that you're part
of a lot of AWS programs.
I run the Cloud Operations Competency,

and we are here with the
Cloud Operations team.
So I wanted to thank you at this point

for being a launch partner
for the Competency.

We launched Cloud Operations
Competency in April 2023,

and Slalom was one of the very
few launch partners there.
So just to kind of level-set everybody,
Cloud Operations in the AWS world
includes five solution areas.

That is: Governance, Cloud
Financial Management,
Observability, Compliance and Auditing,
and centralized Ops Management,
which includes ITSM integrations.
So we validate our Competency Partners
against these solution areas,

against various use cases
within those solution areas,
and we give that stamp of approval
for the best partners out there,
and award the Competency.
So, thanks for being a Competency Partner.

So having established that
you're very well-rounded
and that you have a lot of great offerings
in cloud operations,

maybe you can talk a little
bit about other superpowers

that you think customers
out there are interested in,
what Slalom brings to the table.
- Absolutely.

Some of the other
superpowers that we do have
are around, like,
helping customers establish things
like platform engineering practices,

which is key to being really
efficient with your operations
and your cloud operations.
Modern software development,
building modern platforms and tools.
So we are really excited

about building new
things with our clients,
and helping them evolve their business

to meet, you know, the demands
of what's coming tomorrow.
- Awesome. Awesome.

I just mentioned what the
definition for Cloud Operations is
in the AWS world,
of the five solution areas,
but I just wanted to check with you,

is Slalom defining cloud
ops in the same way?

What does Slalom understand
as cloud operations?
- Right. I think it's very similar.

We could have had a little
conversation even before this

about, like, how certain
phrases and words can be used,
but I do like the structure

that the Competency program
actually put around it,
to define kind of,

"Hey, here are the pillars
and how we think of it."
So I think it actually kind of helps.
I think it's helping people
put a little bit more structure around it,
whereas before they go,

"Well, we think we should be
better with patch management,
and how we monitor, and how we do this."
But it gave much more concrete,
like, "Hey, this is how we think of it,"

where people are able to
kind of rally around it
and use similar language and structure.
- Yeah.

And the way that we
define cloud operations
for our customers,
to define a cloud operational model,
it's super important to integrate
those individual solution areas, right?

It's not just about one
pillar of observability,
but you have to know,
you know, if you get an alert,

how do you integrate that
with your ticketing system?
How do you make sure that

while you do that,
everything is compliant?
And we need partners like Slalom

that can help a customer to
stitch those areas together

and create that overall
cloud operational model
that is optimized and that is, you know,
good for the customer.
So, kind of switching to trends,

I'm super interested in what
kind of, like, bigger trends

do you see in the market right
now, in the immediate future.
- Absolutely. I'll highlight two.
Well, one's probably pretty predictable.

With a lot of excitement
around things like Gen AI,
I think people are starting to realize
the importance of their data
and the governance around that,

how they operate and
maintain those systems
in cost-effective ways.

So I think people have
started to figure out,

like, "Hey, we need to
get back to basics a bit
with how we operate
in order to take advantage
of some of these new things coming out,
to really differentiate ourselves.
That's one trend.
And the other bit is,
I think people have also realized,

kind of with the
macroeconomic state we're in,

that they need to be more
efficient in how they operate,
kind of their larger cloud footprints,

where they are, you know,
appropriately scaled,

they're cost-effective in
terms of how they deploy,

and they're not having to do
one-off programs here and there
to go, "Oh, we need to go figure out a way

to, you know, be more
efficient with our spend
and reduce waste."
So, seeing a lot of that right now.
- So you're saying they should have
an integrated cloud operational model
across five solution areas?
- Couldn't say it better myself.
- Yeah, exactly, perfect. Cool.

So just kind of touching
on some of these trends,

what are some solutions that
Slalom is bringing to market,
or some, like, more recent solutions
that you recently launched?
- Yeah, absolutely.
As it relates to operations and things
that we've spent a lot of time on
are things like platform engineering,

so helping teams build out
scalable, robust platforms

that help them operate their
AWS environments at scale.
And then also things like SRE, which goes

site reliability engineering,
for those not familiar,
which is something that we're seeing
more customers start to rally around,

where they start to take
some of those pillars

and they use that as a part
of their operating model
going to cloud.
So those are two exciting areas
that we're seeing a lot more traction,
and they're frankly fun areas to work in.
- Yeah, that's true.

And you mentioned a
couple of buzzwords there,

but you also said, you know,
it's going back to basics.
I really like that,

because I think that there's
a lot of buzzwords out there.
Somehow, everything, it becomes an LLM
over the last couple of months.
So I just wanted to check with you,

is there any kind of
misconceptions that you see,

that you hear from customers,
or in the market in general?
- I don't know that I would say
there's necessarily big misconceptions.
I think there's a lot of curiosity,
and people are trying to learn

what these things are useful
for, and what they're not.
So I think AWS, for example,
with AWS products and services,

they highlight a lot with
talks at, you know, conferences

of how they leverage
AI to be more efficient

for how they deliver
services for customers,
and I think to also inspire customers
to start to ask them about, like,

"Hey, how should we think
about things like ML and AI?"

And, you know, with
Bedrock released as well,

like, how should we think
about large language models?
So I would say it's more of, like,

you think of, like, a large
learning curve for the industry.

I think people have started
to, like, kind of tick up.

And so they, they wonder,
right, about ChatGPT,
like, things of that nature,
"What could that do for us?
Like, how could we unlock that for us?"
And so the really cool thing there is

we get to put on our
creative hats with them,

and we get to imagine,
like, what could be possible

and what could make sense
for kind of your industry,
the kinds of data you have, or could have,
and do something exciting.
- Yeah. No, I see that too.

And there's a lot of customers
that are very excited
to check out those new services,
but they're a little scared of, you know,
what is the governance around it?

What kind of financial
impact does it have?
And how do I actually connect

these new functionalities
and these use cases
to direct business outcome,

of how much is actually
gonna be in there for me,
top line and bottom line, right?
So those are conversations

that are really important
to have with customers,
and that's where I'm really grateful
for partners like Slalom,

to have these conversations
with our customers
and be sort of the expert in the room,
to kind of level-set everything.
Of course you are in our partner network,
in our partner world.
I can go on my system in AWS,
AWS is very data obsessed,
so I can see what kind of exciting deals
you guys are working on,
and there are a lot,

but maybe you can share
some customer stories

or some deals that you've
recently seen in the market
that Slalom has worked on,
yeah, that excite you.
- Yeah, one I'd like to highlight

is a client we were
wrapping up a project with,
we've been working on for the past year,
building out a completely modern platform.
So the cool thing there is,
you know, they're familiar with AWS,

they've been a client of
AWS for quite some time,

but they really wanted to
take that leap forward,

and they said, "Hey, look,
what does good look like?
We want you to help model that for us
and help build our teams out
so that they can take the reins
and operate those environments.
So we're in the point of that project now,
that bittersweet moment

where they start to
take more of the reins,
and you're so proud of, you know,
what you've built with them

and they're very proud
of what they've built

and what they've accomplished,
and what they've learned.
But what's also been unique about it,
and this is kind of a value-add for Slalom
and kind of our human approach,

is, we've connected them
with other peers of theirs,

and we've started to get
some information sharing
going across some of their peers,

where they realize, "Hey, if
you're able to build this here,
and we can build this,
if we work together,

like, we could actually make
this better for all of us.

So some of those connections
we've been able to do
within the industry,
this is more of a public services story,
it's been very, very cool.
- Yeah, I do agree.

I think, especially when
it comes to service level
or like business objectives,
the consulting partners come in
and they bring a lot of value in,
because it's not, you know,
and, say, I'm just making this up,
a manufacturing company, right?

The manufacturing people, they
only know their own world,
but if you've worked with
10, 15, 20, 50 manufacturing companies,
you can help set those SLOs

and, you know, kind of
create that value through it.

So there's a lot of, it's
exciting stuff going on.
We're about to head into 2024.

I'm wondering what excites
you most about the next year?
What excites you most about 2024?
- What excites me about 2024
is what that sets up for 2025.

So we've talked about
getting back to basics
a little bit with data,

start seeing where things
like large language models
and other capabilities start to go.
So I'm really looking forward to

what kind of experience our
clients are gonna run with that,

and what kinds of things we
can help them bring to market
And I actually think 2024 is gonna be
a giant springboard into 2025.

- Right.
- With what's being built.
So as weird as it sounds,

I'm more excited about
the year after next year
than I am about next year.

- I always say cloud
years are like five years.
You know, like, one year in cloud

is like five years in
normal life. (laughs)
There's so much development.
- Yeah, and part of the excitement also,
and you know, with, like, re:Invent
there's a lot of launches
of products and services and features,

is, and this is specific to
how you operate in the cloud,
how you operate in the cloud
in, like, AWS five years ago
versus how you do it today,
versus 10 years ago,
it's radically different.

So one of the things I do
look forward to in 2024
is, like, helping our customers evolve
to use what is the best for you now
as opposed to, like,

what maybe you set up
in, like, 2015 or 2018,
and how do you continue to improve
and make yourself more efficient,
so you focus on solving for your customers

as opposed to working and
managing your infrastructure.
- Yeah, that's right.

So you talked so much about
the offerings that you have.
I would love to, maybe for you to give
some information to folks out there

of how they can find
out more about Slalom,
or where they should go,
whether it's Marketplace or your website,
or where can they find out more?
- Totally. We are on the AWS Marketplace.
You can find us there.

And if you want just a
quick link, slalom.com/aws
Super simple.
And that's got a lot more information
around, like, Cloud Operations Competency

and other competencies
that we're a part of.
We're part of quite a number
across specific, you know,

operation specialties,
industries, kind of you name it.

So.
- Yeah.

And you're, honestly,
you're doing a terrific job.
I'm always impressed of how well you map
to the individual AWS programs.

It's not easy sometimes, and
you're doing a terrific job.
So at this point,

I thank you for being
a launch partner again
for the Cloud Operations Competency.

I know there's a lot of
exciting stuff in store for you.
I'm excited to see the future,
and yeah, thanks for spending the time.

- Thank you, Frank.
- Awesome.
- Appreciate it.
